text:
Teenager admits Russell Square killing of US tourist in stabbing spree 
Zakaria Bulhan pleads guilty to manslaughter of Darlene Horton on grounds of diminished responsibility Artist sketch of Zakaria Bulhan (right) at court shortly after the attack on Darlene Horton and five others last August. Photograph: Elizabeth Cook/PA View more sharing options Monday 6 February 2017 10.59 GMT Last modified on Monday 6 February 2017 11.01 GMT 
A teenager has pleaded guilty to killing an American tourist and wounding five others in a series of random stabbings in Russell Square, London , in August last year. 
Appearing at the Old Bailey on Monday, Zakaria Bulhan admitted the manslaughter of Darlene Horton, 64, on the grounds of diminished responsibility, and the wounding of five others with intent to do them grievous bodily harm. 
He had been due to stand trial on one count of murder and five counts of attempted murder. 
The 19-year-old, who has paranoid schizophrenia , was arrested on suspicion of murder after being detained at the scene of the knife attack on 3 August. 
Despite initial concern, Scotland Yard said at the time that no evidence had been found of radicalisation or anything to suggest the man in custody was “in any way motivated by terrorism”. 
Bulhan is a Norwegian national of Somali origin who moved to the UK in 2002 and lived in Wandsworth, south London, with his mother, brother and sister at the time of the attack. 
Horton, who was pronounced dead at the scene, was attacked in front of her husband, Richard Wagner, a psychology professor at Florida State University. He had been in London teaching summer classes that had ended that day. They were due to fly back to the US hours after the incident took place. Darlene Horton had been due to fly back to the US shortly after the Russell Square attack. Photograph: Metropolitan police/PA 
She reportedly died while being cradled in the lap of a Spanish tourist after trying to warn others their lives could be in danger. 
After her death, devastated friends of Horton’s paid tribute to the retired special education teacher, calling her an “inspiration”. 
The only British victim was 67-year-old Bernard Hepplewhite from Kent, who was stabbed in the stomach and was seriously injured. 
The other victims were: Martin Hoenisch from the US who was stabbed in the chest; Australians Lillie Selletin, 23, who was stabbed on her back, and lobbyist David Imber, 40, also stabbed in the chest; and Israeli Yovel Lewronski, 18, who was stabbed in her bicep.
